comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It's very posed and a very artificial setting in the studio, yet the beauty of these two children shines through.  This is ageless though time has moved on so much for the subjects.  A beautiful shot.  Thank you.

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content:
it's just wonderful! 
why would they dress up the boy as a girl?

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tammybeck] For centuries male babies were put in dresses - similar to those worn by their sisters. Boys weren't "breeched" until they were toddlers or older. By the 1900s boys graduated from dresses at earlier ages, but it wasn't until the 1920s that rompers and similar became common. I've heard several theories as to why this was a tradition for so long. One I remember hearing was to disguise boys (more "valuable" targets given inheritance rules/etc) from being taken by fairies or human kidnappers. I'd suggest however that it was more hum-drum than that. A stitched pants suit or babygro is more complex and expensive to make than a simple gown. And a gown would take longer to grow out of. Hence stick all babies in cheap and long lasting gowns - regardless of gender :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: A colleague here, who had also been told that dresses were to protect "valuable" boys from the clutches of wily fairies, found confirmation here: www.pitt.edu/~dash/britchange.html (scroll to bottom - Dressing Boys in Girls' Clothes

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Not much to go on in the census, so this is speculative, but I like Hannah L. Murphy as Mrs. M.J., in which case this pair would be Kitty and Willie, 4 and 2. There is no Hannah Murphy in 1901, so she was presumably not married then, and she's a widow in 1911, so I can't tell who M.J. Murphy was...
